home.heroSubtitle: A single entry point for your applications
home.heroDescription:
Omnia centralizes authentication, administration and cross-cutting services (logs, notifications, etc.)
for all your apps.

features.centralisationDesc: Centralize users, logs, and cross-cutting services in one place.
features.securityDesc: Unified authentication and access management across all apps.
features.adminDesc: Simple interface to manage your applications and configuration.
features.observabilityDesc: Centralized logs and metrics to diagnose issues quickly.

applications.subtitle: Add, edit and delete applications. Manage versions (HMAC secrets).
applications.reminder: Reminder: the secret is only shown once when creating a version. Store it in the client app and use the X-Key-Version header.

docs.title: Documentation
docs.subtitle: Learn how to integrate Omnia into your applications.

gettingStarted.introText1: Omnia is a centralized monitoring platform that provides unified logging, activity tracking, and application management for all your applications.
gettingStarted.feature1: Centralized error logging with automatic grouping by fingerprint
gettingStarted.feature2: Activity tracking to monitor user engagement
gettingStarted.feature3: HMAC-based authentication for secure API access
gettingStarted.step1Text: Log into Omnia and create a new application. You'll receive an App ID and a secret key.
gettingStarted.step2Text: Store your App ID and secret securely. The secret is only shown once!
gettingStarted.step3Text: Use the API with HMAC authentication to send logs:
gettingStarted.prereqText: Before integrating Omnia, ensure you have:
gettingStarted.prereq1: An Omnia account with at least one application created
gettingStarted.prereq2: Your App ID, secret key, and key version
gettingStarted.prereq3: A way to compute HMAC-SHA256 signatures in your language

coreConcepts.applicationsText1: Applications in Omnia represent your software projects. Each application has its own isolated data, encryption keys, and access controls.
coreConcepts.applicationsText2: When you create an application, Omnia generates:
coreConcepts.appFeature1: A unique App ID (GUID) to identify your application
coreConcepts.appFeature2: HMAC secret keys for signing API requests
coreConcepts.appFeature3: Encryption keys for securing your log data at rest
coreConcepts.authText1: Omnia supports two authentication methods for your applications:
coreConcepts.authHmac: For machine-to-machine API calls (logging, tracking, etc.)
coreConcepts.authNote: Always use HMAC authentication for automated API calls from your applications. User authentication for the dashboard is handled separately.
coreConcepts.hmacText1: HMAC (Hash-based Message Authentication Code) ensures that API requests are authentic and haven't been tampered with. Every request must include these headers:
coreConcepts.headerKeyVersion: The version of the secret key being used
coreConcepts.headerNonce: Unique identifier (UUID) to prevent replay attacks
coreConcepts.hmacText2: The signature is computed from the request method, path, timestamp, nonce, and body:
coreConcepts.logsText1: Logs in Omnia are structured error and event records. Each log contains:
coreConcepts.logsCategory: Type of log (Error, Security, HTTP, Validation, etc.)
coreConcepts.logsPayload: Additional context as JSON (stack traces, user info, etc.)
coreConcepts.logsText2: Omnia automatically groups similar logs by fingerprint, making it easy to track recurring issues:
coreConcepts.activityText1: Activity tracking allows you to monitor user engagement across your applications. Track anonymous sessions to understand usage patterns.
coreConcepts.activityFeature2: View activity charts with configurable granularity
coreConcepts.activityFeature3: Filter by date range and applications

apiReference.authText: Authentication endpoints for user login and token management.
apiReference.loginDesc: Authenticate with email and password to receive JWT tokens.
apiReference.refreshDesc: Refresh an expired access token using the refresh token.
apiReference.getAppsDesc: List all applications you have access to.
apiReference.createAppDesc: Create a new application. Returns the app details and HMAC secret.
apiReference.logText: Send and retrieve logs (requires HMAC authentication for POST).
apiReference.logNote: POST /api/log requires HMAC authentication. GET endpoints require JWT authentication.
apiReference.createLogDesc: Send a new log entry. Use HMAC headers for authentication.
apiReference.getLogsDesc: Retrieve logs with optional filters (application, date range, category, level).
apiReference.getDistinctDesc: Get logs grouped by fingerprint with occurrence counts.
apiReference.patchLogsDesc: Mark logs as patched or unpatched.
apiReference.activityText: Track and retrieve user activity data.
apiReference.trackDesc: Track an anonymous user session. Use HMAC headers for authentication.
apiReference.getActivityDesc: Retrieve activity data as time series.

bestPractices.secretText1: Properly managing your HMAC secrets is crucial for security.
bestPractices.secretWarning: Never commit secrets to version control or expose them in client-side code!
bestPractices.secretTip1: Store secrets in environment variables or a secrets manager
bestPractices.secretTip2: Rotate secrets periodically by creating new versions
bestPractices.secretTip3: Use different secrets for development and production
bestPractices.secretTip4: Disable old secret versions after rotation
bestPractices.secretSuccess: Best practice: Use your platform's secrets manager (AWS Secrets Manager, Azure Key Vault, HashiCorp Vault, etc.)
bestPractices.secretDockerText: For Docker deployments, use environment variables:
bestPractices.errorText1: Handle Omnia client errors gracefully to avoid affecting your application:
bestPractices.errorTip1: Never let Omnia errors crash your application
bestPractices.errorTip3: Implement retry logic with exponential backoff
bestPractices.errorAsyncText: Always wrap Omnia calls in try-catch:
bestPractices.errorRetryText: For critical logs, implement retry logic:
bestPractices.logText1: Structure your logs consistently for better searchability and grouping.
bestPractices.levelDebug: Detailed information for debugging (not for production)
bestPractices.levelWarning: Unexpected situations that don't affect functionality
bestPractices.logGoodText: Good: Use structured payloads with consistent keys:
bestPractices.logBadText: Bad: Don't embed all data in the message:
bestPractices.logStackText: Include stack traces in the payload for debugging:

troubleshooting.auth403Cause1: User doesn't have access to the requested application
troubleshooting.auth403Cause2: Attempting to modify resources you don't own
troubleshooting.hmacText1: HMAC signature errors are usually caused by incorrect signature computation.
troubleshooting.hmacWarning: The most common mistake is using the wrong timestamp format or JSON serialization.
troubleshooting.hmacFormatText: The signature must be computed from this exact format:
troubleshooting.hmacCheck1: Timestamp is in milliseconds (13 digits), not seconds
troubleshooting.hmacCheck4: Newlines in the data-to-sign are \n, not \r\n
troubleshooting.hmacCheck5: Secret is correctly base64-decoded before use
troubleshooting.corsText: If you're calling Omnia from a browser, ensure CORS is configured on your Omnia instance.
troubleshooting.timeoutText: Increase timeout settings for slow network connections.
troubleshooting.duplicatesText: If you see duplicate logs, ensure you're not calling the logging function multiple times. Use debouncing for error boundaries that might fire repeatedly.
troubleshooting.encodingText: Always use UTF-8 encoding for request bodies. Ensure special characters in messages are properly encoded.

faq.generalA1: Omnia is a centralized monitoring platform that provides error logging, activity tracking, and application management. It helps you monitor all your applications from a single dashboard.
faq.generalA2: Omnia provides a REST API that works with any language. We provide code examples for C#, JavaScript/TypeScript (React, React Native, Next.js, Express), Python, Go, and PHP.
faq.generalA4: Logs are grouped by fingerprint, which is computed from the application, category, level, normalized message, and stack signature. This helps identify recurring issues.
faq.securityA1: Log messages and payloads are encrypted at rest using multiple layers of encryption and per-application keys.
faq.securityQ2: How are the API calls secured?
faq.securityA2: API calls are secured using HMAC signatures, which prove both authentication and integrity. Each request has a unique signature that can't be reused, preventing replay attacks.
faq.securityA4: Create a new secret version in the dashboard, update your application to use the new version, then disable the old version. Both versions can be active during the transition.
